title: Canon Rebel T7 vs T7i: Which Is Better?
description: So you’re finally ready to stop pretending your phone camera is “good enough” and step into the world of real photography. Enter: Canon’s Rebel T7 and T7i. These two are like brothers from the same parents but raised on wildly different allowances. Let’s break it all down so you don’t end up staring at a [...] The post Canon Rebel T7 vs T7i: Which Is Better? appeared first on Canon Rumors.
author: Heidi Loren

html:
So you’re finally ready to stop pretending your phone camera is “good enough” and step into the world of real photography. Enter: Canon’s Rebel T7 and T7i. These two are like brothers from the same parents but raised on wildly different allowances.

Let’s break it all down so you don’t end up staring at a spec sheet like it’s written in ancient runes.

Key Features: Comparison

_________________________________________________________

Canon Rebel T7 Pros & Cons

Canon EOS Rebel T7

4.7

  • 24.1 Megapixel CMOS (APS-C) sensor with is 100–6400 (H: 12800)
  • Built-in Wi-Fi and NFC technology
  • 9-Point AF system and AI Servo AF
  • Optical Viewfinder with approx 95% viewing coverage
  • Use the EOS Utility Webcam Beta Software (Mac and Windows) to turn your compatible Canon camera into a high-quality webcam. Compatible Lenses- Canon EF Lenses (including EF-S lenses, excluding EF-M lenses)

Pros:

  • Doesn’t destroy your bank account
  • Image quality still solid
  • Super beginner-friendly — like, Grandma could use it
  • Built-in Wi-Fi for instant bragging rights
  • Great battery life
  • Compatible with a ton of Canon lenses (like, a ridiculous amount)

Cons:

  • Autofocus is… fine… if your subject is a statue
  • Live View focusing is slow enough to go make coffee while it figures itself out
  • No touchscreen — feels like you’re using a Game Boy in 2025
  • No mic input = a damper on YouTube dreams
  • 3 fps burst = good for still life, bad for sports or toddlers on sugar
  • Fixed screen, so no vlogging or sneaky high-angle shots

Canon Rebel T7i Pros & Cons

Canon EOS Rebel T7i

4.7

  • 24.2 Megapixel CMOS (APS C) sensor
  • Built in Wi-Fi, NFC and Bluetooth Lens used: EF S 18-55 millimeter f by 4-56 IS STM (at focal length of 55 millimeter)
  • High Speed continuous shooting at up to 60 fps Weight Approx 1877 ounce or 532 grams (including battery pack and SD memory card) Approx 1711 ounce or 485 gram (body only)
  • Metering Range: EV 1-20 (room temperature, evaluative metering)
  • Use the EOS Utility Webcam Beta Software (Mac and Windows) to turn your compatible Canon Camera into a high-quality webcam

Pros:

  • Autofocus is sharp, fast, and makes you look way better than you are (no offense)
  • Dual Pixel AF means Live View is actually usable
  • Flip-out touchscreen = vlogging, selfies, and high-angle wizardry
  • 6 fps burst means it can handle action better than your reflexes
  • Mic input, thank the camera gods
  • DIGIC 7 processor handles noise better, especially in low light

Cons:

  • It’s pricier (but not crazy expensive)
  • No 4K video — still stuck in the “Full HD” era
  • All plastic body — won’t survive a fall off a cliff (or a toddler toss)
  • Slightly shorter battery life than the T7
  • More buttons = more things to accidentally mess up
  • You may end up actually reading the manual (gasp)

Who’s This Actually For?

Canon Rebel T7

  • You just want better pictures than your phone can take
  • You’re new to photography and want something simple
  • You’re buying your teen/kid a starter camera
  • You don’t care about fancy features — just point, shoot, and vibe

Canon Rebel T7i

  • You plan to get into video or vlogging
  • You want to learn and grow without upgrading in 6 months
  • You shoot action, wildlife, or anything that moves (not statues)
  • You care about performance AND convenience
  • You want to press buttons and actually know what they do eventually

5 Compatible Lenses 

Let’s be real — your camera’s only as good as the glass on the front. Here are 5 killer lenses that’ll level you up, no matter which Rebel you pick:

1. Canon EF 50mm f/1.8 STM (“Nifty Fifty”)
2. Canon EF-S 10-18mm f/4.5-5.6 IS STM
3. Canon EF-S 24mm f/2.8 STM (“Pancake Lens”)
4. Canon EF 75-300mm f/4-5.6 III
5. Sigma 18-35mm f/1.8 DC HSM Art

The Final Verdict: T7 or T7i?

  • T7 = solid, simple, great for total beginners or people on a budget.
  • T7i = worth the extra cash if you want faster performance, better autofocus, touchscreen, and actual video features.

If you’re just getting into photography and want to play it safe, go with the T7. It’ll teach you a lot and make you love the craft.
But if you’re serious about learning, want to shoot video, or plan to keep the camera for years, go with the T7i. It’s got way more growing room.

Either way, you’re winning. The real flex isn’t the gear — it’s how you use it.

When you purchase through links on our site, we may earn an affiliate commission. Here's how it works.

Heidi is a featured writer, photographer, and artist based in England. With little over a decade's experience, a sharp eye for detail, and a passion for visual and written expression, she brings stories to life through both lens and language. As an editorial photographer, she captures compelling portraits—often with her favorite Canon EOS R5 and RF 85mm lens.
